intro: Linochilus nevadensis, commonly known as the Nevada linochilus, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Nevada. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its umbellate inflorescence. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high elevations, showcasing adaptations to arid and cold environments. Its small, white to pale purple flowers bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species in its native range.
